question: [File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: All validators] [Gas estimation] Do validator functions have deterministic execution time regardless of input, or can an attacker craft worst-case inputs (e.g., regex backtracking, long strings) that cause gas estimation to significantly underestimate actual costs, leading to out-of-gas panics mid-transaction? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Recovery mechanism] When IsSHA256Hash validates transaction hashes in TokenWrapper's RecoverZig function, can an attacker provide invalid hash formats that bypass validation but cause recovery operations to fail silently, leaving tokens permanently stuck? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: StringLengthInRange()] [Token metadata] When validating token symbol, name, or description lengths in Factory module, can an attacker exploit missing unicode normalization to create tokens with visually identical names but different storage representations, confusing users and front-ends? (Medium)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsURI() + SHA256HashOfURL()] [IBC metadata] When validating and hashing IBC connection metadata (client IDs, connection IDs, channel IDs), can an attacker exploit the lack of URI validation before hashing to inject malicious metadata that corrupts the IBC routing table? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: All validators] [Consensus failure] If different validator nodes have different versions of the govalidator library or regex engine, can validation inconsistencies cause state divergence where some validators accept transactions that others reject, leading to chain splits? (Critical)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: All validators] [State transition] If validation functions are called during state transition (BeginBlock/DeliverTx/EndBlock) without proper gas metering, can an attacker submit transactions with inputs that require excessive validation computation, causing block production delays and chain liveness issues? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [IBC integration] When IsSHA256Hash validates packet commitment hashes in IBC middleware, can an attacker pass invalid hash formats that cause IBC acknowledgment failures, leaving tokens permanently locked in the TokenWrapper module wallet? (Critical)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: StringLengthInRange()] [DEX integration] When StringLengthInRange validates pool names in DEX module's CreatePool function, can an attacker bypass length limits to create pools with names that overflow database fields or cause indexing failures? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: SHA256HashOfURL()] [Factory integration] When SHA256HashOfURL generates token identifiers in Factory module's CreateDenom function, can an attacker exploit hash collision or predictability to create duplicate denoms that override existing token configurations? (Critical)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsURI()] [TokenWrapper integration] When IsURI validates IBC channel URIs in TokenWrapper module's UpdateIBCSettings function, can an attacker bypass validation to register malicious relay endpoints that redirect IBC packets to attacker-controlled chains? (Critical)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: StringLengthInRange() + IsSHA256Hash()] [Length mismatch] Does calling StringLengthInRange(hash, 64, 64) provide the same validation as IsSHA256Hash(), and can this redundancy cause confusion where one validation passes but the other fails due to character set differences? (Low)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: All validators] [Thread safety] Are any of these validator functions using shared state or non-thread-safe dependencies (like regex compilation) that could cause race conditions when multiple transactions validate inputs concurrently in BeginBlock/EndBlock? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: All validators] [Error handling inconsistency] Do all validator functions consistently return boolean values without error details, forcing upstream callers to make generic error messages that don't indicate which specific validation failed, hindering debugging of failed transactions? (Low)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: StringLengthInRange() + IsURI()] [Compound validation] When both length and URI format are validated, can an attacker craft inputs that pass length checks but fail URI validation after blockchain state is partially updated, causing state inconsistency in token metadata? (Medium)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsURI() + SHA256HashOfURL()] [Validation bypass] Since SHA256HashOfURL has disabled URI validation (commented out), can an attacker exploit this inconsistency by passing non-URI inputs that should have been caught by IsURI but proceed to generate hashes used as token identifiers? (Critical)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: SHA256HashOfURL() + IsSHA256Hash()] [Hash consistency] If SHA256HashOfURL produces a hash and it's later validated by IsSHA256Hash, can inconsistencies in hex formatting (case, leading zeros) cause the validation to fail, breaking the hash-then-verify pattern in IBC packet processing? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Regex engine limits] Can an attacker exploit regex engine implementation limits (maximum input length, stack depth) by passing extremely long strings that cause the regex matcher to fail silently and return false for valid hashes? (Medium)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Anchor bypass] Are the ^ and $ anchors in the regex pattern properly matched to the full string, or can multi-line input modes or flags cause the regex to match only a portion of the input, accepting longer strings? (High)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Hash entropy validation] Does IsSHA256Hash only validate format without checking hash entropy, allowing an attacker to use low-entropy hashes (e.g., all zeros, repeated patterns) that might cause unintended behavior in hash-based indexing? (Low)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Non-ASCII characters] Does the regex properly reject non-ASCII characters that might be present in the input, or can UTF-8 multi-byte sequences bypass validation and cause encoding issues in downstream processing? (Medium)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Regex compilation cost] Is the regex pattern compiled on every call to IsSHA256Hash, causing excessive CPU usage when validating thousands of hashes in a single block, potentially enabling DoS through computational exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Newline characters] Can an attacker inject newline characters (\n, \r) into hash strings that satisfy the regex but cause multi-line parsing errors in transaction logs or state exports? (Low)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Leading/trailing whitespace] Does the regex properly reject inputs with leading or trailing whitespace, or can an attacker pad hash strings with spaces that are later trimmed, causing validated inputs to differ from stored values? (Medium)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Null byte injection] Can an attacker include null bytes in the input string that terminate the string early in C-style string handling (if bridged to C code), bypassing the 64-character length requirement? (Low)

[File: zutils/validators/strings.go] [Function: IsSHA256Hash()] [Empty string validation] Does IsSHA256Hash properly reject empty strings, or can an attacker pass empty input that causes nil pointer dereferences in modules expecting validated hash strings? (Medium)
